@Ruby, @Julia: As discussed, I tried making 'None' as a default value for rescue interface for hardware types, but it breaks in config. Had posted this patch (19) with that implementation to see if I missed anything. Further discussed with Dmitry [1]and it seems we cannot do that. We would need tohave 'no-rescue' as the default value for hardware types. In migration script and in  the _convert_to_version() we can set the rescue interface to 'no-rescue' without looking at driver type as driver.rescue would always be 'None' for classic drivers. Will post the patches shortly.

(1 comment)

Hi Shiv, I looked at our code. The rescue interface is more similar to the console and inspect interfaces, than the storage interface. And for those interfaces, the default is to set them to None for classic drivers, and to 'no-X' for hardware types. I think we should do a similar thing for rescue too. Having said that, I believe that if the interface is set to None, the code (via the driver factory stuff) will change it to be the default, in our case, 'no-rescue'. Which makes the _convert_to_version() in objects/node.py easier to deal with and we don't have to add an online-data-migration. (we will, of course have to test that this is true...)"}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2017-12-13 15:36:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2017-12-13 16:19:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

'}, {'created': '2017-10-06 17:41:54.000000000', 'message': "Adds rescue_interface to base driver class

This commit adds `rescue` interface to `BaseDriver` and implements
this interface for `fake` hardware type.
It also adds configuration parameters
'[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' and
'[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface'. The default value of
configuration parameter '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' is
`no-rescue`.

Partial-bug: #1526449

"}, {'created': '2017-11-10 17:04:19.000000000', 'message': "Adds rescue_interface to base driver class

This commit adds `rescue` interface to `BaseDriver` and implements
this interface for `fake` hardware type. It adds configuration
parameters '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' and
'[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface'. The default value of
configuration parameter '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' is
`no-rescue`.
It also adds DB migration that sets the 'rescue_interface' to
'no-rescue' for the nodes managed by classic drivers and to
the value of '[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface' for the nodes
managed by hardware types.

Partial-bug: #1526449
Co-Authored-By: Jay Faulkner <jay@jvf.cc>
Co-Authored-By: Josh Gachnang <josh@pcsforeducation.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jesse J. Cook <jesse.j.cook@member.fsf.org>

"}, {'created': '2017-11-13 06:25:43.000000000', 'message': "Adds rescue_interface to base driver class

This commit adds `rescue` interface to `BaseDriver` and implements
this interface for `fake` classic driver and `fake-hardware`
hardware type. It adds configuration parameters
'[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' and
'[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface'. The default value of
configuration parameter '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' is
[`noop`,`no-rescue`].

It also adds DB migration that sets the 'rescue_interface' to
the value of '[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface' or `noop` for
the nodes managed by hardware types.

Partial-bug: #1526449
Co-Authored-By: Jay Faulkner <jay@jvf.cc>
Co-Authored-By: Josh Gachnang <josh@pcsforeducation.com>

"}, {'created': '2017-12-03 16:41:16.000000000', 'message': "Adds rescue_interface to base driver class

This commit adds `rescue` interface to `BaseDriver` and implements
it for `fake-hardware` hardware type. It adds configuration
parameters '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' and
'[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface'. The default value of
configuration parameter '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' is
`no-rescue`.

It adds new rescue states and a new 'rescue' field to the Node
object. It also adds objects.node.Node._convert_to_version().
The method handles converting the new rescue_interface field
between different versions of the Node.

Partial-bug: #1526449
Co-Authored-By: Jay Faulkner <jay@jvf.cc>

"}, {'created': '2017-12-05 10:12:50.000000000', 'message': "Adds rescue_interface to base driver class

This commit adds 'rescue' interface to 'BaseDriver' and implements
it for 'fake-hardware' hardware type. It adds configuration
parameters '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' and
'[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface'. The default values of these
configuration parameters is 'None'.

It adds new rescue states and a new 'rescue' field to the Node
object. It also adds objects.node.Node._convert_to_version().
The method handles converting the new rescue_interface field
between different versions of the Node.

"}, {'created': '2017-12-08 07:12:09.000000000', 'message': "Adds rescue_interface to base driver class

This commit adds `rescue` interface to `BaseDriver` and implements
it for `fake-hardware` hardware type. It adds configuration
parameters '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' and
'[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface'. The default value of
configuration parameter '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' is
`no-rescue`.

It adds new rescue states and a new 'rescue' field to the Node
object. It adds objects.node.Node._convert_to_version().

between different versions of the Node.

for hardware type managed nodes to 'no-rescue'.

commit_message:
Adds rescue_interface to base driver class

This commit adds `rescue` interface to `BaseDriver` and implements
it for `fake-hardware` hardware type. It adds configuration
parameters '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' and
'[DEFAULT]/default_rescue_interface'. The default value of
configuration parameter '[DEFAULT]/enabled_rescue_interfaces' is
`no-rescue`.

It adds new rescue states and a new 'rescue' field to the Node
object. It adds objects.node.Node._convert_to_version().
The method handles converting the new rescue_interface field
between different versions of the Node.

Partial-bug: #1526449
Co-Authored-By: Jay Faulkner <jay@jvf.cc>
Co-Authored-By: Josh Gachnang <josh@pcsforeducation.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jesse J. Cook <jesse.j.cook@member.fsf.org>
Co-Authored-By: Mario Villaplana <mario.villaplana@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Aparna <aparnavtce@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Shivanand Tendulker <stendulker@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I1534247bf207a20a7a58534988192aef392eaff2

commit_message:
Add search_opts in func list of ManagerWithFind type classes

In patch I96339778fa69c379863078250d5dfa7172f2c1b2, it called
self.list with search_opts, but some subclasses of ManagerWithFind
do not have search_opts in function list, this make some list
functions and show by name functions fail and throw 'unexpected
keyword argument search_opts' error. This patch will fix it.

Change-Id: Ic4b65c0e5900a0e3e19155d5d9d42d5063c3137d
Closes-Bug: #1738917
Closes-Bug: #1738918
(cherry picked from commit 7e4a376426578d1bc48c8d9824e6c6a722724f7a)

commit_message:
Add Angular keystone user creation action

- fix users rest API to handle description,
  project, and enabled attribute properly
- fix hz-password-match to work, but also so
  it uses model-based checks rather than HTML
  element lookups
- add schema form password-confirm type

To Test
 - set 'users_panel': True in settings.py

Co-Authored-By: Cindy Lu <clu@us.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Richard Jones <r1chardj0n3s@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Shu Muto <shu-mutou@rf.jp.nec.com>

Change-Id: I2e8f5ac1dbfae9634fa5b72f7f6c0278d5a81249
Partially-Implements: blueprint ng-users

"}, {'created': '2018-01-08 17:40:28.000000000', 'message': "Ignore ansible errors occuring during log collection

commit_message:
Ignore ansible errors occuring during log collection

It is possible the tripleo-inventory role fails, for instance if the
undercloud install didn't go as planned and it couldn't generate
a stackrc.

Ignore errors to collect at least some amount of logs.

Change-Id: I5a4d3e67a7144e76987859fe8aae33fe809d32e4

[{'account_id': 27585, 'date': '2018-01-04 15:27:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-04 15:27:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 12171, 'date': '2018-01-07 06:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Configure inline mode transport for Connectx4/LX

We need inline mode transport to be able to hw offload in the above cards.

commit_message:
Configure nova_cell1.conf to use placement for reschedules

Nova now calculates alternate hosts in the scheduler and
sends those to the cell for reschedules in case a build on
a given compute node fails.

The cell conductor needs to claim resources against the
alternate hosts in Placement during a reschedule, therefore
it needs to be configured to talk to the placement service.

Part of blueprint return-alternate-hosts

Change-Id: Ie599968d9e7537e551fe6d9deb63a91b256b1e11

commit_message:
Implements AIDE Intrusion Detection System

Introduces a puppet service to configure AIDE Intrusion
Detection. This service init's the database and copies the
new database to the active naming. It also sets a cron job,
using email is `AideEmail` is populated, otherwise the reports
are sent to /var/log/aide/.

AIDE rules can be supplied as a hash, and should the rules ever
be changed, the service will populate the new rules and re-init
a fresh integrity database.

Related-Blueprint: tripleo-aide-database
Change-Id: Iac2ceb7fc6b610f8920ae6f75faa2885f3edf6eb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-03 17:48:23.000000000', 'message': "Raise MarkerNotFound if BuildRequestList.get_by_filters doesn't find marker

For some reason, probably because build requests are meant to be short lived
and we don't get a lot of bugs about paging misbehavior, when paging instances
with a marker, we didn't raise MarkerNotFound if we didn't find the marker in
the list of build requests. Doing so would match what we do when paging over
cells and listing instances using a marker. Once we find the marker, be that
in build_requests, or one of the cells, we need to set the marker to None to
stop looking for it elsewhere if we have more space to fill our limit.

For example, see change I8a957bebfcecd6ac712103c346e028d80f1ecd7c.

This patch fixes the issue by raising MarkerNotFound from BuildRequestList
get_by_filters if there is a marker and we didn't find a build request for
it. The compute API get_all() method handles that as normal and continues
looking for the marker in one of the cells.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflicts are due to not having
bb7c6ebb5648150430363c12ebc25a1c405ca79f in Ocata.

Change-Id: I1aa3ca6cc70cef65d24dec1e7db9491c9b73f7ab
Closes-Bug: #1737856
(cherry picked from commit 1706e3989157f912bce99beb99c75216a064eb2d)
(cherry picked from commit 344029b94ad7ff4667403a851d33c3ddb4e97b4b)
"}]
commit_message:
Raise MarkerNotFound if BuildRequestList.get_by_filters doesn't find marker

For some reason, probably because build requests are meant to be short lived
and we don't get a lot of bugs about paging misbehavior, when paging instances
with a marker, we didn't raise MarkerNotFound if we didn't find the marker in
the list of build requests. Doing so would match what we do when paging over
cells and listing instances using a marker. Once we find the marker, be that
in build_requests, or one of the cells, we need to set the marker to None to
stop looking for it elsewhere if we have more space to fill our limit.

For example, see change I8a957bebfcecd6ac712103c346e028d80f1ecd7c.

This patch fixes the issue by raising MarkerNotFound from BuildRequestList
get_by_filters if there is a marker and we didn't find a build request for
it. The compute API get_all() method handles that as normal and continues
looking for the marker in one of the cells.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflicts are due to not having
bb7c6ebb5648150430363c12ebc25a1c405ca79f in Ocata.

Change-Id: I1aa3ca6cc70cef65d24dec1e7db9491c9b73f7ab
Closes-Bug: #1737856
(cherry picked from commit 1706e3989157f912bce99beb99c75216a064eb2d)
(cherry picked from commit 344029b94ad7ff4667403a851d33c3ddb4e97b4b)

commit_message:
Use "ip neigh" instead of "arp -n" in worlddump.py

Worlddumping on a system without net-tools package gets an error showing
"arp: not found". As iproute2 can also show arp tables, we use it
instead.

Change-Id: I0cd83e6d14959dc5a1147c487b11f27fb92aa20a

[{'created': '2018-01-03 15:20:25.000000000', 'message': 'Add doc/requirements.txt file with doc requirements

The sphinx jobs need to find doc requirements in either
test-requiremnts.txt or doc/requirements.txt. Putting them directly in

commit_message:
Add doc/requirements.txt file with doc requirements

The sphinx jobs need to find doc requirements in either
test-requiremnts.txt or doc/requirements.txt. Putting them directly in
to tox.ini, not so much.

Amended to use matching stable/ocata requirements.

Change-Id: I98a43b511a6949fa4f00c26eec224d24d6fa6588
(cherry picked from commit 4187d2fc4adbebf84e5d03e2f5c1c587b4bc9d04)

More information, some service templates have a pattern where we use either the parameter_default value, or the heat generated one stored in DefaultPasswords from overcloud.yaml:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/puppet/services/heat-engine.yaml#L136

[{'created': '2017-12-06 19:28:35.000000000', 'message': "Manage MysqlRootPassword in constants

Instead of generated a MySQL root password from the Heat Template,
make the password generated among other passwords so we can re-use the
data across undercloud-container re-install or updates, when Heat and
environments are re-generated.
Note: it'll change the MySQL password to be 25 caracters instead of 10,
so we're improving the security here.

commit_message:
Manage legacy OS::TripleO::RandomString resources in constants

Instead of generated OS::TripleO::RandomString from the Heat Template,
make the password generated among other passwords so we can re-use the
data across undercloud-container re-install or updates, when Heat and
environments are re-generated.

Note: it keeps the same password constraints as it was in THT.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Martin Andr <m.andre@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I9da2220ce5635d06c2ca9a21bd07eb2b6ee50aaa
Related-Bug: #1736779

commit_message:
Replace outdated image info in guest_cloud_init doc.

The link of Ubuntu Cloud Archive is broken and was referring to daily
buildings. Using official released images instead.

Change-Id: I78352c72c667cae93c0865f79ded0ed5caff7560
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

(2 comments)

Thanks for working on this! The POST_FAILURE for the api-ref job is an infra problem that should be fixed soon, but you can build these yourself using `tox -eapi-ref`, and then if the build succeeds you can open the files in api-ref/build/html to see how they look. I found one problem that prevented it from building and at least one other that would have been noticeable by looking at it, I pointed them out inline.

While you're there, would you mind cleaning up the extra whitespace? Gerrit marks it with a red block. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 26874, 'date': '2017-12-27 11:36:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-12-27 19:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

subject: Remove unused arguments from _commit_port_binding
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-08 22:58:29.000000000', 'message': "Remove unused arguments from _commit_port_binding

The ML2 plugin method _commit_port_binding is defined to receive the
need_notify and try_again arguments as inputs. The method doesn't use
those inputs at all. This patch removes the arguments from the method
signature

Change-Id: I8e5b6639de2db257afad634b0b12f242e20b17f9
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unused arguments from _commit_port_binding

The ML2 plugin method _commit_port_binding is defined to receive the
need_notify and try_again arguments as inputs. The method doesn't use
those inputs at all. This patch removes the arguments from the method
signature

Change-Id: I8e5b6639de2db257afad634b0b12f242e20b17f9

subject: Add ceph storage strategy
messages:
[{'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-02 07:20:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-02 07:41:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-03 01:20:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-03 05:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 25113, 'date': '2018-01-03 08:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

It looks like your change has effected the unit test. I suggest that you have to make sure the related unit tests modified properly.'}, {'account_id': 22608, 'date': '2018-01-03 10:09:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Ceph object storage support swiftclient. So I don't think it is necessary to add a new file ceph.py. I just reuse the swift.py and it works fine for me. :)"}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-03 11:28:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2018-01-03 12:20:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1 Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Hey, I have my 5 cents about this change.

First, for that type of change we should define Blueprint. We need that.
Second, where are the unittests for ceph storage?

IMO you should also add co-authored-by tag:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-04 01:15:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 22608, 'date': '2018-01-04 02:16:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-04 02:55:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Maciej Jozefczyk swift's functions were called in many place,it's hard to realize a new strategy class."}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-04 05:40:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 25113, 'date': '2018-01-04 07:53:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Generally, we add co-authored-by in this format:
Co-authored-by: <name> <launchpad id>
For example:
Co-authored-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>
It's better to add the developer of related patch, not just a company.

One more nitpick, pay attention to the capital letter."}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-04 08:40:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-04 09:06:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-01-04 09:52:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

1. agree with Maciej Jozefczyk about a new blueprint and new unitests for this change;

2. for the name of this new strategy, radosgw is more specific than ceph;

3. Ceph RadosGW supports both swift and s3 interfaces, it would be great to support both of them in Trove (or we can change to name strategy by protocol: swift and s3, then Trove can be used with Swift, Ceph RadosGW, AWS S3, etc.);

4. The current implementable of Ceph RadosGW swift strategy is almost identical to the default swift strategy before the SLO change, we should find ways to avoid code duplication.'}, {'account_id': 25113, 'date': '2018-01-04 10:10:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(4 comments)

See inline comments. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-05 02:39:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-05 02:41:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@all, maybe we should create a new blueprint.'}, {'account_id': 26472, 'date': '2018-01-08 05:57:55.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

It's a big project to realize a new storage project.Eventhough, this patch can work."}, {'account_id': 22694, 'date': '2018-01-09 02:31:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 22694, 'date': '2018-01-09 02:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.context/blob/newton-eol/oslo_context/context.py#L74

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.context/blob/master/oslo_context/context.py#L192

It can be seen from the n version to the latest version, tenant has been modified into project_id, so I think this change at least does not apply to the latest version of trove'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-02 07:20:16.000000000', 'message': 'add ceph storage strategy

support ceph object storage(radows gateway),some function are realized

[{'created': '2016-09-11 06:01:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add __lt__(self,other) in base.Version

It has __gt__, __eq__, __ne__ in the Version, but it lacks __lt__.

Change-Id: I83d27f7c4bfda6213aa37c8507cf1aefc51a910a

commit_message:
Add __lt__(self,other) in base.Version

It has __gt__, __eq__, __ne__ in the Version, but it lacks __lt__.
Therefore, I add it.

Change-Id: I83d27f7c4bfda6213aa37c8507cf1aefc51a910a

commit_message:
Update pypowervm minimum requirement to 1.1.10

1.1.10 is required for PowerVM virt driver networking support [1][2]

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/422512/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523216/

Change-Id: Ifb5a6c3902f5ac97048fb96341c476b255cbd117

commit_message:
FIX inject password error
The envirenment variable LIBGUESTFS_BACKEND = direct is not enabled by default in docker container.
Without it, GuestFS() init failed.

Change-Id: I5d2f6643324c6397793c53a58424bd49effd8f3f

* for jinja expressions there is available built-in
  function 'os_env'. In short:

  - env_name: !os_env ENV_NAME, default_name

  can be replaced with:

  - env_name: {{ os_env('ENV_NAME', 'default_name') }}

  available jinja includes, loops (for generate various amount of
  slave nodes specified with an environment variable).

commit_message:
Add jinja2 support for devops YAML templates

* for jinja expressions there is available built-in
  function 'os_env'. In short:

  - env_name: !os_env ENV_NAME, default_name

  can be replaced with:

  - env_name: {{ os_env('ENV_NAME', 'default_name') }}

* devops templates can be rendered with jinja2, so there are
  available jinja includes, loops (for generate various amount of
  slave nodes specified with an environment variable).

Change-Id: Ia43ae96abd290a49495935f971300730c30e537c

New keys for l2_network_device:

- pxe_bootp_file: filename of PXE loader, default='pxelinux.0'
- pxe_bootp_server: IP address of TFTP server that should be used
                    instead of the libvirt host. default=None

Change-Id: I5b15bcdb623638df939eddf78cf1ff90efa08a7f
"}, {'created': '2017-12-08 20:14:05.000000000', 'message': "Allow to specify a remote tftp server and pxe loader name

New keys for l2_network_device:

- pxe_bootp_file: filename of PXE loader, default='pxelinux.0'
- pxe_bootp_server: IP address of TFTP server that should be used
                    instead of the libvirt host. default=None

Change-Id: I5b15bcdb623638df939eddf78cf1ff90efa08a7f
"}]
commit_message:
Allow to specify a remote tftp server and pxe loader name

New keys for l2_network_device:

- pxe_bootp_file: filename of PXE loader, default='pxelinux.0'
- pxe_bootp_server: IP address of TFTP server that should be used
                    instead of the libvirt host. default=None

Change-Id: I5b15bcdb623638df939eddf78cf1ff90efa08a7f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-03 19:41:50.000000000', 'message': "Devstack: install qemu-system-x86 on RHEL

This wasn't installed for me on a devstack run on a fresh RHEL 7.4 box.
Make sure it's installed as we depend on it by default.

Change-Id: I4faadb2d73afd298ffb1b7690b23f72800123f77
"}]
commit_message:
Devstack: install qemu-system-x86 on RHEL

This wasn't installed for me on a devstack run on a fresh RHEL 7.4 box.
Make sure it's installed as we depend on it by default.

Change-Id: I4faadb2d73afd298ffb1b7690b23f72800123f77

(14 comments)

I've made some initial comments.  They are mostly minor, but I do note that your calculation of virtual free capacity is not exactly the same as that in the capacity weigher, where reserved_capacity is also taken into account.  This suggests to me that we ought to have a common utility method for determining virtual free space and that it should be used by the various places in the scheduler that do this."}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-07-30 06:36:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-07-30 06:43:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Tom Barron
Thanks for your comments above. I have updated the patch according to most of them. 

I have taken into account the reserved_percentage to calculate the virtual free capacity as it is already there.

The LOG information in update_service capabilities() is intended to report all the capacity dicts includes all pools and backends, so I haven't modify it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-07-30 19:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

@Huang Zhiteng

Thanks comments for the patch set. For the comments to suggest modifying test_update_service_capabilities(), I will explain it in more detail.
1) update_service_capabilities() doesn't have the "context" parameter, but it needs to call the utcnow(). 
2) update_service_capabilities() calls get_capacity() and get_capacity() needs "context" parameter.
3) If get_capacity() calls get_admin_context() directly, get_admin_context() will call utcnow(), then the utcnow() will be called twice in test_update_service_capabilities and such case will trigger a fault by mock.

Should test_update_service_capabilities() know anything with the "context" parameter for get_capacity() function? The fault occurs just because calling utcnow() twice is not allowable for mock. I just haven't a good idea to deal with it besides the temporary method in patch set now.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-08-04 08:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

Adding the logic to scheduler.update_service_capabilities() isn't probably a good idea because in the case when there were N schedulers (N>1) deployed, every update from c-vol services will cause N notifications (of exact same content) sent to celiometer.  And the way it's implemented right now (get_capacity() calls get_pools()) will result DB queries (in _update_host_state_map()).  Maybe it isn't much of a problem but I want us to think it through."}, {'account_id': 17444, 'date': '2015-08-05 04:33:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems/NetApp_FC_CI'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2015-08-10 14:57:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Hi Xin,
Couple of questions, this seems like it does what's intended but I'm curious why the existing stats reporting mechanisms can't be leveraged here?  My concern is we've had a fair bit of work going into the stats reporting and keeping it updated; I would hate to introduce another maintenance point for this if we don't have to.

I fully admit that I might be missing some details here in your proposal, if so feel free to update the commit message to explain things a bit more clearly.

Also, note that the blueprint could probably use some updating, because again as I mentioned we do in fact capture stats info on utilization and the scheduler take that into account (assuming you use the weighing filter).

Finally... what's up with the change lines in the volume/utils.py file?"}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-11 02:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-11 02:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Huang Zhiteng
Thanks for your comments. I have addressed your comments about test cases. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-11 02:52:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@John Griffith
Thanks for your comments. :-)
Actually, I thought the stats captured here for different pools and backends would be reported to ceilometer at the same time. It would be helpful for ceilometer service to audit with the notifications besides the sparse reports here and there. It maybe a rough impression of the whole storage usages at a glance.  It is not another mechanism and just report another kinds of stats and not conflict with others. And I thought the ceilometer service needs all kinds of stats for auditing. :-)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-08-11 03:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

(5 comments)

You need to add tests for get_capacity_and_notify and when you do you'll realize that there is a problem, get_capacity returns a dict of dicts and _notify_capacity_usage calls _usage_from_capacity with it but _usage_from_capacity is expecting only a single dictionary of those.

Also I don't think we should send a notification to ceilometer with each update from the volume nodes, because that message is broadcasted to all schedulers, so if you have 10 volume nodes and 3 schedulers you'll be sending 30 notifications on every reporting interval with almost the same information.

I would prefer to either send this information periodically in the schedulers (so in our example we would decrease from 30 notifications to 3) or only send to ceilometer notification for the pool and backend  we have received the update from."}, {'account_id': 10621, 'date': '2015-08-19 13:36:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-08-21 08:51:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

You are totally right!!  Sorry.

I still believe we shouldn't be doing notifications this way, because (even if we change code in this patch to only send updated data - different than all data when there's an update) we are sending to ceilometer the same notification multiple times (one for each scheduler) and we should be sending it only once.

And it would get even worse once we have Active-Active deployments.

The best way to handle this is to create a new method in the scheduler called notify_capabilities and modify rpc call update_service_capabilities in scheduler/rpc.py so and add to that method another RPC call to that notify_capabilities method using cast method but with no fanout."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-08-21 12:07:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified+1

@Gorka Eguileor
Thanks!
For the last comment, if I have understood right, the suggestion is to add a new code path which is similar as  update_service_capabilities(), the new method can be named as notify_service_capabilities().

1) _publish_service_capabilities() calls a new scheduler rpc call, it will be a cast and fanout=false, which allows only one scheduler to deal with it.
2) when scheduler gets the rpc, the new method notify_service_capabilities() in host_manager.py will call get_capacity_and_notify() to notify.

Is that what you mean exactly? If I'm wrong, please correct me.

Then does the same volume service always rpc call the same scheduler? If not, will it be a problem to compare the usage data changed or not for the scheduler will be a different one?   And can one scheduler get all the storage usage since other volume services don't rpc call it?

Thanks
Xiaohui
Xiaohui"}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-08-24 09:17:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Basically yes, but:

In 1) instead of creating a new scheduler rpc call you can use the one we already have scheduler.rpcapi.update_service_capabilities and make 2 rpc calls in there, the one we have now and the new one without fanout.

In 2) you only send modified data to ceilometer, to do this you need to keep a copy with old data in the scheduler.  This new data only gets updated in update_service_capabilities and only when data has changed, in which case you update the previous data with current data and replace current data with received data.  On the new method we only send data when it has changed and to detect this we do:

if timestamp of received data is newer to timestamp of current data:
  compare with current data and send notification if different
else if timestamp of received data is newer to timestamp of saved old data:
  compare with old data and send notification if different
else:
  ignore received data

It doesn't matter which node receives the request, worst case you will send a repeated notification on active-active deployments (when we allow them)."}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-24 14:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

@Gorka Eguileor
Thanks so much for the detailed explanation!
With the way suggested, does it mean that I can't notify all the pools/backends usage at the same time? (means each time notified, ceilometer service can have all the pools/backend usage samples in one time slot, although only one of them is changed). And I can only notify the usage of one backend and its pools which have reported usage info during one reporting period thru volume service? If it is the case, will do all the logic in volume service work? To process the usage data and notify ceilometer in the volume service, a new method named "get_usage_and_notify()" just after _append_volume_stats(). Will it work?

Thanks
Xiaohui'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-08-25 11:57:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Sorry for not explaining it clearly.  What I mean is that you make 2 rpc calls, one that goes to all schedulers (so they can update) and another that only goes to 1 (doesn't matter which).

So in cinder/scheduler/rpcapi.py

 def update_service_capabilities(self, ctxt,         
                                 service_name, host, 
                                 capabilities):      
     # FIXME(flaper87): What to do with fanout?      
     cctxt = self.client.prepare(fanout=True)        
     cctxt.cast(ctxt, 'update_service_capabilities', 
                service_name=service_name, host=host,
                capabilities=capabilities)           
     cctxt = self.client.prepare(version='1.9')        
     cctxt.cast(ctxt, 'notify_service_capabilities', 
                service_name=service_name, host=host,
                capabilities=capabilities)           

Probably best to discuss this on IRC."}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2015-08-26 06:23:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Gorka,

I'd rather create a new separate RPC API instead of stuffing one call into update_service_capabilities."}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-26 07:07:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-26 07:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

@Gorka Eguileor 

Great thanks for the detailed explanation. I have tried the suggested way, but have not finished yet. Before that, I have made patch set 13 based on another solution which moves all the logic from scheduler to the volume manager. Will you have a review for it?

@Huang zhiteng

Thanks for the comments. Patch set 13 moves the logic from scheduler to the volume manager, will you have a review for it?


Thanks xiaohui'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-08-26 08:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Verified+1

-1: I don't think we want this logic in the Volume nodes, because while that will work fine now, once we move to Active-Active configurations we will be sending duplicated information to Ceilometer.  I for one would like to do this right from the beginning."}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-27 07:53:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

@Gorka Eguileor

Thanks for the comments. But I don't quite understand, current file volume/manager.py has so many notifications there, will they send duplicated notifications when active-active deployment is used? 

For only notifying updated data, I thought I'd better send the notifications periodically no matter they are updated or not. As Huang Zhiteng pointed out that ceilometer service doesn't know whether the volume node is down or just not changed after such a long time not receiving any data. How do you think about it?

And if we send periodic data (no matter it is updated or not), will the suggested way you have mentioned resolve the duplicated notifications when active-active deployment is used?



Thanks
Xiaohui"}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-08-27 08:14:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

@Gorka Eguileor

I don't know much about the active-active deployment. If we have 3 same cinder volume service, will they return _report_driver_status() with the same volume_stats? Will the timestamp be same in returned volume_stats especially?

Thanks
Xiaohui"}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-08-27 10:31:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Yes manager has many notifications, but if you look at them they are for operations that are happening on the node, which makes sense because they will not be reported by any other node in the cluster (no duplication), but virtual free capacity of a storage backend will be the same between different nodes in the cluster.

If they are not updated you don't have to send them again, Ceilometer is for collecting measurements, so you don't need to send the same measurement multiple times, and he should care whether you are dead or just not getting any operations or your backend storage is not changing it's capacity.

Yes, with the method I mentioned it should fix duplication of information sent to Ceilometer.

In Active-Active they will each report stats at different points in time (even if they have the same frequency) so the timestamps will be different, and whether the data is the same or not depends on whether there have been changes in the backend storage or not."}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2015-08-27 20:17:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1

The change as-is seem ok to me. I do agree with Gorka that we shouldn't spam these notifications to ceilometer from every c-vol service in an A-A environment, but as-is for L if the choice is no notifications or too many I would side towards potentially sending too many.

I think we probably will have a need to implement the infrastructure to allow for more of this type of reporting and handling it gracefully in an A-A configuration, but I'm not convinced it needs to be tackled right now in this patch."}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-08-27 21:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

In my experience if we implement it this way we'll have something that "works" so we will most likely not change it for a long time after we have Active-Active configurations running, because we will always have other priorities that come first and we'll keep telling ourselves, "well, it is working after all".  Why do something in a way we know we'll have to change not so far away?'}, {'account_id': 12924, 'date': '2015-08-27 22:37:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: -Code-Review

Oops, meant to have a 0 vote on my last comment. Anyway, I agree with you Gorka, my main point was that if its a choice between letting this slip and not merge in L vs fixing the notifications and rpcapi for A-A HA I would rather have this feature since other than that issue it looks fine, thats all.

Either way my guess is that more work should be done to generalize a solution for reporting anything from c-vol services to ceilometer when running the c-vol's in A-A, I'm not entirely sure that implementation would be completed by solving the problem with just this patchset or if there would need to be additional changes as well. Does that make sense?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-08-28 02:48:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Verified-1

Hi All,

I have updated the patchset to 19. Among these, 4 main versions of implementations are included. 

patchset 1-11: calculate and notify in scheduler(update_service_capabilities)
This way, will have duplicated notifications due to multiple schedulers.


patchset 12: calculate and notify in scheduler (update_service_capabilities), but only notify updated stats.
This way, will have duplicated notifications due to multiple schedulers.


patcheset 13: calculate and notify in volume service (in _report_driver_status), and only notify updated stats
This way, will have duplicated notifications due to multiple volume services (active-active deployment)


patcheset: 15~19: calculate and notify in scheduler( create a new rpccall named notify_service_capabilities)
this way, will no duplicated notifications although in active-active deployment


So, which one do you think is the better?


Thanks
Xiaohui'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-09-02 02:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

I may be missing something since I haven't looked at this for a long time, but it looks to me that there's something not quite right. If we receive the cast rpc before the call rpc, won't we skip sending ceilometer data?

It would be great if you could point out on IRC what I'm missing to see.

Some comments are needed in the code and a brief explanation of the logic in the commit message would be great."}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-11-16 15:17:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

@Gorka Eguileor
Great thanks for the valuable comments! I need some time to look into them and will find you in IRC to talk about the logic after that. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-11-17 15:37:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 32:

I think this will not work as expected. Imagine a case with 2 schedulers (S1, S2) and 1 c-vol (CV):

Initial state:
 S1 has service_states[CV]=X0, service_states_last[CV]=X0
 S2 has service_states[CV]=X0, service_states_last[CV]=X0

CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1)
 S1 receives update_service_capabilities(X1)
 S1 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1)
 S1 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)  updated is set in host_manager.py:466
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1)

Now we have:
 S1 has service_states[CV]=X1, service_states_last[CV]=X1
 S2 has service_states[CV]=X1, service_states_last[CV]=X0

There are no changes and CV sends same data again: update_service_capabilities(X1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1)
 CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1)
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1)
 S2 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1)
 S2 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)  updated is set in host_manager.py:469
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1)

So we end up reporting the same data twice and I think that's why I was suggesting to timestamp the data on c-vol and then on scheduler's update_service_capabilities do:

 capab_old = self.service_states.get(host, {})
 if self._is_updated(capab_old, capab_copy):
     self.service_states_last[host] = capab_old
 self.service_states[host] = capab_copy

And in scheduler's notify_service_capabilities do:

 capa_newest = self.service_states.get(host, {'timestamp': 0})
 if capabilities['timestamp'] > capa_newest['timestamp']):
  updated = self._is_updated(self.service_states[host], capabilities)
 elif capabilities['timestamp'] > self.service_states_last[host]['timestamp']:
  updated = self._is_updated(self.service_states_last[host], capabilities)
 else:
  LOG.debug('Skipping capabilities, for being too old')

But this is something that we should all agree on, do we prefer sending duplicate data to ceilometer or if it's just enough sending the most up to date data.

Or maybe I'm imagining things and your solution works and it's my solution that fails.  XD"}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-11-24 17:05:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

(14 comments)

Thanks for the detailed and clear explanation. After some thoughts, I think your method will work. Great thanks! And I replied the comments about your concern. Please have a review. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-11-25 17:52:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

@Gorka Eguileor

I worked through my code path again as your scenario, the result is as below. If I'm wrong, please correct me.
I copied my code path here (It's exactly what I have submitted for the last patchset in order to describe it more easily.

 437         capab_old = self.service_states.get(host, {})
 438         if not self._is_updated(capab_old, capab_copy):
 439             self.service_states_last[host] = capab_old
 440
 441         self.service_states[host] = capab_copy
 442
 443         LOG.debug("Received %(service_name)s service update from "
 444                   "%(host)s: %(cap)s",
 445                   {'service_name': service_name, 'host': host,
 446                    'cap': capabilities})
 447
 448         self._no_capabilities_hosts.discard(host)
 449
 450     def notify_service_capabilities(self, service_name, host, capabilities):
 451         """Notify the ceilometer with updated volume stats"""
 452         if service_name != 'volume':
 453             LOG.debug('Ignoring %(service_name)s service update '
 454                       'from %(host)s',
 455                       {'service_name': service_name, 'host': host})
 456             return
 457         updated = []
 458
 459         capa_new = self.service_states.get(host, {})
 460         timestamp = timeutils.utcnow()
 461
 462         if not capa_new:
 463             updated = self._is_updated(capa_new, capabilities)
 464         else:
 465             if timestamp > self.service_states[host]["timestamp"]:
 466                 updated = self._is_updated(self.service_states[host],
 467                                            capabilities)
 468                 if not updated:
 469                     updated = self._is_updated(
 470                         self.service_states_last.get(host, {}),
 471                         self.service_states.get(host, {}))
 472
 473         if updated:
 474             capab_copy = dict(capabilities)
 475             capab_copy["timestamp"] = timestamp
 476             self.service_states_last[host] = capab_copy
 477             self.get_usage_and_notify(capabilities, updated, host, timestamp)

I used your scenario case:
The case is with 2 schedulers (S1, S2) and 1 c-vol (CV):
Initial state: to make things easy, we use (capa, timestamp) tuple to describe whole capabilities. (capa just mean capabilites without timestamp).
 S1 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
 S2 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)

CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1)

 S1 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1), timestamp=T3, self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T3), --line 441, self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0) --line:438-439, service_states_last is not changed.

 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1), timestamp=T4, capa_old =(X1, T3) --line 437, self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T4), self.service_states_last[CV]=capa_old=(X1, T3) --line 438-439, service_states_last is changed.
 S2 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1), timestamp=T5, capabilities=(X1), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T4), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X1, T3),

So I didn't see the twice report for the same capabilities. If I'm wrong, please correct me.

I have worked through your code path and your case scenario for some time as below and I found something I haven't noticed before. If I'm wrong, please correct me.
With your code path, we do timestamp in cinder-volume. I think the method update_service_capabilities() in cinder/manager.py is the candidate place to do this, and in method _publish_service_capabilities() in cinder/manager.py, the two rpcapi update_service_capabilites() and notify_service_capabilites() will use the same capabilities with the same timestamp.

I have copied your code as below.  
In method update_service_capabilities in cinder/scheduler/host_manager.py do:

 capab_old = self.service_states.get(host, {})
 if self._is_updated(capab_old, capab_copy):
     self.service_states_last[host] = capab_old
 self.service_states[host] = capab_copy

And in scheduler's notify_service_capabilities do:
 capa_newest = self.service_states.get(host, {'timestamp': 0})
 if capabilities['timestamp'] > capa_newest['timestamp']):
  updated = self._is_updated(self.service_states[host], capabilities)
 elif capabilities['timestamp'] > self.service_states_last[host]['timestamp']:
  updated = self._is_updated(self.service_states_last[host], capabilities)
 else:
  LOG.debug('Skipping capabilities, for being too old')

For the code in update_service_capabilities(), we have two choices, one is to do timestamp again which is already in original code path, and the other is not to do timestamp, for we have already do timestamp in cinder-volume. We will try the two choices with the same scenario cases later.

Your scenario case is as below.
The case is with 2 schedulers (S1, S2) and 1 c-vol (CV):
We will start with the first choice: do the timestamp again in method update_service_capabilities() in cinder/scheduler/host_manager.py.
 
Initial state: to make things easy, we use (capa, timestamp) tuple to describe whole capabilities. (capa just mean capabilites without timestamp).
 S1 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
 S2 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1, T1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1, T1)
 S1 receives update_service_capabilities(X1, T1), timestamp=T2, self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T2), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0) 
 S1 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1, T1), capabilities=(X1, T1), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T2), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0), 
                                                  T1<T2, T1>T0, updated is set in the "elif" sentence as above.
 S1 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1, T1), timestamp=T3, self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T3), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)

Now we have:
 S1 has service_states[CV]=(X1, T2), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
 S2 has service_states[CV]=(X1, T3), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
CV sends same data again: update_service_capabilities(X1, T4) and notify_service_capabilities(X1, T4)
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1, T4), timestamp=T5, self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T5), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0) (for the service_states_last[CV] is not changed)
 S2 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1, T4), capabilities=(X1, T4), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T5), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0),
                                                  T4<T5, T4>T0, updated is set in the "elif" sentence as above.
                                                  
 S2 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)  
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1)

So the same capa is reported twice.

For the second choice, we do not do the timestamp again in method update_service_capabilities() in cinder/scheduler/host_manager.py.
The same scenario will be:

 S1 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
 S2 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1, T1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1, T1)
 S1 receives update_service_capabilities(X1, T1), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
 S1 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1, T1), capabilities=(X1, T1), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0), 
                                                  T1=T1, T1>T0, updated is set in the "elif" sentence as above.
 S1 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)

 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1, T1), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
Now we have:
 S1 has service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
 S2 has service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
There are no changes and CV sends same data again: update_service_capabilities(X1, T2) and notify_service_capabilities(X1, T2)
 CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1, T2) and notify_service_capabilities(X1, T2)
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1, T2), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T2), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0) (for the updated not set)
 S2 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1, T2), capabilities=(X1, T2), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T2), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0),
                                                  T2=T2, T2>T0, updated is set in the "elif" sentence as above.
                                                  
 S2 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)  
 S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1)

So the same capa is reported twice.

I believe it's tricky. If I'm wrong, please correct me.

Thanks
Xiaohui'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-12-02 10:58:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 32:

@Gorka Eguileor

I studied the fail case you have provided, I differentiate it as first run and second run.

The first run, CV sends the capabilities:
S1: update_service_capabilities
S1: notify_service_capabilities
S2: update_service_capabilities

The second run, CV send the same capabilities:
S2: notify_service_capabilities
S2: update_service_capabilities
S1: update_service_capabilities

Below is walking of the my code path in previous comments, just to make things clear.

Initial state: to make things easy, we use (capa, timestamp) tuple to describe whole capabilities. (capa just mean capabilites without timestamp).
 step 1. S1 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
 step 2. S2 has service_states[CV]=(X0, T0), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
    CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1)
 step 3. S1 receives update_service_capabilities(X1), timestamp=T1, self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), --line 441, self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0) --line:438-439,   service_states_last is not changed.
 step 4. S1 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1), timestamp=T2, capabilities=(X1), self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0), 
                                                  T2>T1 --line 465, updated is set at --line 469. self.service_states_last[CV]=(X1, T2) --line 476
 step 5. S1 reports to ceilometer diff(X1, X0)
 step 6. S2 receives update_service_capabilities(X1), timestamp=T3, self.service_states[CV]=(X1, T3), --line 441, self.service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0) --line:438-439, service_states_last is not changed.
Now we have:
 S1 has service_states[CV]=(X1, T1), service_states_last[CV]=(X1, T2)
 S2 has service_states[CV]=(X1, T3), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
CV sends update_service_capabilities(X1) and notify_service_capabilities(X1)

 step 7. S2 receives notify_service_capabilities(X1), timestamp=T4, capabilites=(X1), service_states[CV]=(X1, T3), service_states_last[CV]=(X0, T0)
                                                      T4>T3 --line 465, updated is set at --line 469. self.service_sates_last[CV]=(X1, T4) --line 476

Step 4 and step 7 are almost the same.

For S1, it receives the first time update_service_capablities in step 3, and it receives the first time notify_service_capabilities in step 4. Timestamp in step 4 is larger than Timestamp in step 3. In this case, S1 will reports.

For S2, it receives the first time update_service_capabilites in step 6, and it receives the first time notify_service_capabilities in step 7. Timestamp in step 7 is larger than Timestamp in step 6. In this case, S2 will reports too. S2 doesn't know the udpate_service_capabilities() in step 6 is in the first run, and doesn't know the notify_service_capabilities() in step 7 is in the second run either. 

Acutally, the code path sequence here for S1 and S2 is the same, they are sure to behave as the same. S1 and S2 are independent with each other, their states won't affect the other one's states. In this case, I think timestamp will not work. And I don't think we can find something to differentiate the 2 cases. How do you think about it?

Thanks
Xiaohui"}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2015-12-04 12:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

What is the structure of the capabilities? It seems that it is well defined, so you shouldn't send an arbitrary dict over RPC but create and send a versioned object instead.

We want to use versioned objects to provide interoperability of services running in different versions to support rolling upgrades. If I understand correctly you have the structure defined in REQUIRED_KEYS in host_manager, so this shouldn't be hard to switch that to OVO. As an example you can take a look on my patches that convert request_spec dict to an object."}, {'account_id': 14274, 'date': '2015-12-23 08:20:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 33:

It calculates virtual free capacity for

values. It will also notify various
capacity info to Ceilometer service.
The notification only occurs when
volume status is updated. It will give
users a bit knowledge about the current
storage usage.

As there are multiple schedulers and volumes, the
patch contains the logic only to send changed
capacity info to ceilometer as possible. It adds a
new rpc call named as notify_service_capabilities()
which fanout is false in volume manager which to
send capbilities to only one of the schedulers.

Implements: blueprint capacity-headroom
Change-Id: Iff033d1b591fb3d9c0a5b9732c0c17d96ddbf712
'}, {'created': '2015-12-24 07:03:43.000000000', 'message': 'Calculate virtual free capacity and notify

It calculates virtual free capacity for
pool and backend which reports definite
values. It will also notify various
capacity info to Ceilometer service.
The notification only occurs when
volume status is updated. It will give
users a bit knowledge about the current
storage usage.

As there are multiple schedulers and volumes, the
patch contains the logic only to send changed
capacity info to ceilometer as possible. It adds a
new rpc call named as notify_service_capabilities()
which fanout is false in volume manager which to
send capbilities to only one of the schedulers.

commit_message:
Calculate virtual free capacity and notify

It calculates virtual free capacity for
pool and backend which reports definite
values. It will also notify various
capacity info to Ceilometer service.
The notification only occurs when
volume status is updated. It will give
users a bit knowledge about the current
storage usage.

As there are multiple schedulers and volumes, the
patch contains the logic only to send changed
capacity info to ceilometer as possible as. It adds
a new rpc call named notify_service_capabilities()
which fanout=false in volume manager. This means
that only one scheduler will receive it and send
the notification.

Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: lisali <xiaoyan.li@intel.com>

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint capacity-headroom
Change-Id: Iff033d1b591fb3d9c0a5b9732c0c17d96ddbf712

commit_message:
Agent message signing spec

Ability to cryptographically sign messages sent from
murano-engine to the agents in order to reject messages
that are coming from malicious users

Change-Id: I03b6e5835aa3534b29d7e281c5c90eb320b97e22

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

For more detials information, please refer to:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

Change-Id: Ib02738563f5ae3712e1074a3b08c693ea7cdea79
(cherry picked from commit b8ad99f30b4c9a9ed496d31f941f092fee4b58fe)

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

For more detials information, please refer to:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

Change-Id: Ifa689b590378f58d7abe2a52e8b92f5f32dc5196

doc: Minor rework of usage doc

Reorder some section to highlight those that are totally unique to pbr
rather than simply modified.

commit_message:
Change how path munging works for sphinx docs

The 'import tools' line is fragile as it depends on how things are
executed as to whether or not '.' is in the python path.

Do the sphinx path munging before importing it.

Also, remove reference to modules/autoindex which does not exist and
thus causes sadness from warning-is-error.

Moves documentation requirements into doc/requirements.txt

Depends-On: Ib121961c5a953a434e7b333cd70f7838a2671f69
Change-Id: I23691aa1d0ea038ec1215e6199015529ddd92de4

commit_message:
Add ansible/ansible to zuul

We'd like to run OpenStack tests on changes to Ansible. Before we do
that and report back to github, we should add ansible/ansible to the
config and then update the shade test config to list ansible/ansible in
the required-projects for the ansible-devel test.

Change-Id: Ib5e35315fc9ffe6fa8873ad4975309d9820e1feb

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: Ifaaf656effff20ef08214f111645a3b5fc8b4d28
(cherry picked from commit d68b53f0568afcc171f0f773469a023c11fe3079)

If this is addressing a bug in mock, why not propose the fix to that project?'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2017-12-13 14:04:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I already have, a few months ago:

[1] https://github.com/testing-cabal/mock/issues/393
[2] https://bugs.python.org/issue30587
[3] https://github.com/testing-cabal/mock/issues/396
[4] https://bugs.python.org/issue32092

And I didn't get any feedback from the project maintainers, or any say if they have any chance of merging or not. In fact, looking at the mock library in github, no change has been made since last year:

[5] https://github.com/testing-cabal/mock/

We've already talked about this topic during the nova meeting a few weeks ago, and the general consensus was to propose those fixes to oslotest, in order for other projects to be able to benefit from them as well.

[6] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-meeting/%23openstack-meeting.2017-11-30.log.html#t2017-11-30T14:28:31"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-05 15:14:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > 
 > [6] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-meeting/%23openstack-meeting.2017-11-30.log.html#t2017-11-30T14:28:31

OK, I can support adding it here while we wait for upstream to land those patches.

Could you add some examples of how to use the feature properly in doc/source/user (probably by adding a new file to that directory)?"}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-01-05 15:28:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sure, will do.

Also, just an FYI, the patches mentioned in the Needed-By in the commit message have this patch applied, and the unit tests are running (nova-oslotest-mock-tox-py27 and nova-oslotest-mock-tox-py35 - I had to temporarely add a different zuul job because the normal ones were not getting this patch as a dependency).'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-01-05 16:48:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-01-05 16:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-01-05 17:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-01-05 17:32:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-01-05 17:53:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2018-01-07 04:46:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-01 01:31:46.000000000', 'message': "Adds mock autospec fixture

In typical unit tests, almost all of the dependencies are mocked or
patched (mock.patch), without any guarantee that the mocked methods
actually exist, or if their signatures are respected (see below). Because
of this, actual issues can easily be overlooked and missed, as the unit
tests are wrongfully passing.

The mock.Mock class accepts a spec as an argument, which only solves half
the problem: it only checks if an attribute exists, based on the given
spec. It does not guarantee that the given attribute is actually a method,
or if its signature is respected. Some unit tests may pass the autospec
argument, but mock doesn't support it at the moment.

mock.patch, mock.patch.object, mock.patch.multiple accept an autospec
argument, but because of a bug, it cannot be used properly.

Adds a fixture which replaces mock.Mock and mock.MagicMock with
subclass which accepts the autospec argument, and on call, it will
check the signature of the called method / function.

Adds a function which replaces mock.mock._patch with a subclass, which
treats the autospec argument properly (consumes the self / cls argument),
and sets autospec=True by default, unless otherwise specified.
WARNING: this function is not a fixture, and in order to benefit from it,
it will have to be called as EARLY as possible, before any test classes
are loaded, otherwise the original mock.mock._patch is used instead.

Change-Id: I0e4a55fbf4c1d175726ca22b664e240849a99856
Closes-Bug: #1735588
"}, {'created': '2017-12-01 01:33:26.000000000', 'message': "Adds mock autospec fixture

patched (mock.patch), without any guarantee that the mocked methods
actually exist, or if their signatures are respected (see below). Because
of this, actual issues can easily be overlooked and missed, as the unit
tests are wrongfully passing.

The mock.Mock class accepts a spec as an argument, which only solves half
the problem: it only checks if an attribute exists, based on the given
spec. It does not guarantee that the given attribute is actually a method,
or if its signature is respected. Some unit tests may pass the autospec
argument, but mock doesn't support it at the moment.

mock.patch, mock.patch.object, mock.patch.multiple accept an autospec
argument, but because of a bug, it cannot be used properly.

Adds a fixture which replaces mock.Mock and mock.MagicMock with
subclass which accepts the autospec argument, and on call, it will
check the signature of the called method / function.

Adds a function which replaces mock.mock._patch with a subclass, which
treats the autospec argument properly (consumes the self / cls argument),
and sets autospec=True by default, unless otherwise specified.
WARNING: this function is not a fixture, and in order to benefit from it,
it will have to be called as EARLY as possible, before any test classes
are loaded, otherwise the original mock.mock._patch is used instead.

Needed-By: I3636833962c905faa0f144c7fdc4833037324d31
Needed-By: I4484e63c97bd1cdde3d88855eabe7545784f365e

Closes-Bug: #1735588

Change-Id: I0e4a55fbf4c1d175726ca22b664e240849a99856

actually exist, or if their signatures are respected (see below). Because
of this, actual issues can easily be overlooked and missed, as the unit
tests are wrongfully passing.

The mock.Mock class accepts a spec as an argument, which only solves half
the problem: it only checks if an attribute exists, based on the given
spec. It does not guarantee that the given attribute is actually a method,
or if its signature is respected. Some unit tests may pass the autospec
argument, but mock doesn't support it at the moment.

mock.patch, mock.patch.object, mock.patch.multiple accept an autospec
argument, but because of a bug, it cannot be used properly.

Adds a fixture which replaces mock.Mock and mock.MagicMock with
subclass which accepts the autospec argument, and on call, it will
check the signature of the called method / function.

Adds a function which replaces mock.mock._patch with a subclass, which
treats the autospec argument properly (consumes the self / cls argument),
and sets autospec=True by default, unless otherwise specified.
WARNING: this function is not a fixture, and in order to benefit from it,
it will have to be called as EARLY as possible, before any test classes
are loaded, otherwise the original mock.mock._patch is used instead.

Needed-By: I3636833962c905faa0f144c7fdc4833037324d31
Needed-By: I4484e63c97bd1cdde3d88855eabe7545784f365e

Closes-Bug: #1735588

Change-Id: I0e4a55fbf4c1d175726ca22b664e240849a99856

commit_message:
Adds mock autospec fixture

In typical unit tests, almost all of the dependencies are mocked or
patched (mock.patch), without any guarantee that the mocked methods
actually exist, or if their signatures are respected (see below). Because
of this, actual issues can easily be overlooked and missed, as the unit
tests are wrongfully passing.

The mock.Mock class accepts a spec as an argument, which only solves half
the problem: it only checks if an attribute exists, based on the given
spec. It does not guarantee that the given attribute is actually a method,
or if its signature is respected. Some unit tests may pass the autospec
argument, but mock doesn't support it at the moment.

mock.patch, mock.patch.object, mock.patch.multiple accept an autospec
argument, but because of a bug, it cannot be used properly.

Adds a fixture which replaces mock.Mock and mock.MagicMock with
subclass which accepts the autospec argument, and on call, it will
check the signature of the called method / function.

Adds a function which replaces mock.mock._patch with a subclass, which
treats the autospec argument properly (consumes the self / cls argument),
and sets autospec=True by default, unless otherwise specified.
WARNING: this function is not a fixture, and in order to benefit from it,
it will have to be called as EARLY as possible, before any test classes
are loaded, otherwise the original mock.mock._patch is used instead.

Needed-By: I3636833962c905faa0f144c7fdc4833037324d31
Needed-By: I4484e63c97bd1cdde3d88855eabe7545784f365e

Closes-Bug: #1735588

Change-Id: I0e4a55fbf4c1d175726ca22b664e240849a99856

commit_message:
Zuulv3 iptables

The switch to Zuulv3 changed the way iptables works, breaking all
the multinode gates. This makes it work again until we can find a
better solution.

Change-Id: Ia188038f6d0ffd8302086ff99981726be5ddccab

commit_message:
Add new tables for unified limits

This patch addes two tables called "registered limit"
and "limit" for unified limits feature.

Co-Authored-By: Colleen Murphy<colleen@gazlene.net>

Change-Id: I67441454fc17d20e50e6fa7199c07014c97d83f6

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-08 11:00:02.000000000', 'message': 'Skip ansible-lint test against roles

In order to decouple changes in the roles repositories from changes
needed in other repositories due to the ansible-lint test, the roles
repositories will skip all dependent roles when executing the lint test.
The roles can be updated in time as patches are submitted to those
repositories. In order to do that, we need to stop symlinking the
role into the same directory where its dependent roles are and place
it to its own directory so we can ignore the dependent roles in
ansible-lint.

Change-Id: I49c01fb63054e45bae5ae45a89cce986579959de
Closes-Bug: #1737310
(cherry picked from commit 4bb840d2deec944c9add2858fcdb4b083edd7bde)
'}]
commit_message:
Skip ansible-lint test against roles

In order to decouple changes in the roles repositories from changes
needed in other repositories due to the ansible-lint test, the roles
repositories will skip all dependent roles when executing the lint test.
The roles can be updated in time as patches are submitted to those
repositories. In order to do that, we need to stop symlinking the
role into the same directory where its dependent roles are and place
it to its own directory so we can ignore the dependent roles in
ansible-lint.

Change-Id: I49c01fb63054e45bae5ae45a89cce986579959de
Closes-Bug: #1737310
(cherry picked from commit 4bb840d2deec944c9add2858fcdb4b083edd7bde)

commit_message:
Collect logs in post playbook for multinode

Collect logs after main job is finished, so that we'll have logs
in any case of job result.
Do it for multinode jobs only, because ovb nodes are wiped right
after job finishes and collecting logs there requires a bit
different effort.
Depends-On: I7b7582469b01116bbe754af07c81cc698355d8c4

Change-Id: I600ade65052d28978c9d395323c8b86ed213fd38

commit_message:
Centralize list of irrelevant files

For python-ironic-inspector-client-tempest-dsvm:
- moves the list of irrelevant-files from project.yaml to
  legacy-*-jobs.yaml
- adds more irrelevant files to the list
- removes requirements.txt from the list of irrelevant files, since
  we want the job to run if this file changes

For openstack-tox-functional, the irrelevant files were added to
that job in openstack-zuul-jobs repo (in
e8a0a62fdc936f8b3e307951c95c3848597124aa).

Change-Id: I3bd1c2b552108f8fccf504696f09034bfe2c40f6
(cherry picked from commit 9a683efcbeec5d4bcf85f8190eca7afe8210182d)

commit_message:
Add librados-dev to distro package list

librados2-dev is needed to build 'cradox' from gnocchi's ceph
requirements.

Change-Id: Iad26778c188966b942b66d593cbd2f553ae7f627

port, 8775.

Closes-bug: #1722584

commit_message:
Checksum-fill proxied metadata replies

Sometimes a proxied metadata reply can be dropped by
the hypervisor because of an invalid checksum.  Always
fill-in the checksum just like we do for DHCP replies.

Change-Id: I46987da3bf05577ff0a51a490f26cf2be3c3c266
Closes-bug: #1722584

commit_message:
Clean trailing whitespace in HciCeph roles

Idce7aa04753eadb459124d6095efd1fe2cc95c17 introduced some extra
whitespace. This is a follow up patch to clean it.

Change-Id: I71e3387ad234444737d4430753f9bf9aaa2054c2

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-04 21:14:22.000000000', 'message': "Tolerate ports in tag discover

The tag parsing assumed there would only be one colon in the path,
which does not hold when there is a port in the registry path.

Once again we're bitten by image names not being real URLs.

Change-Id: Ia2d0efeaa269d61f6669b141d745ab2c1bb306da
Closes-Bug: #1735565
(cherry picked from commit 451ba333ea37f53df4ee2db8a96b191eb463af41)
"}]
commit_message:
Tolerate ports in tag discover

The tag parsing assumed there would only be one colon in the path,
which does not hold when there is a port in the registry path.

Once again we're bitten by image names not being real URLs.

Change-Id: Ia2d0efeaa269d61f6669b141d745ab2c1bb306da
Closes-Bug: #1735565
(cherry picked from commit 451ba333ea37f53df4ee2db8a96b191eb463af41)

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-19 14:13:48.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup mistral-api override

The kolla mistral-api images now has all the requirements to run httpd,
there is no need to carry the patch in our tripleo overrides file
anymore.

The remaining overrides for installing httpd are left untouched as
these are only useful for running a TLS proxy for services not
supporting it natively, which seems very specific to TripleO.

Change-Id: Id8387c8b05f8f316fdab98b6dfe33d6fddf36f19
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup mistral-api override

The kolla mistral-api images now has all the requirements to run httpd,
there is no need to carry the patch in our tripleo overrides file
anymore.

The remaining overrides for installing httpd are left untouched as
these are only useful for running a TLS proxy for services not
supporting it natively, which seems very specific to TripleO.

Change-Id: Id8387c8b05f8f316fdab98b6dfe33d6fddf36f19

commit_message:
Deprecate old OVB playbook in CI

Now OVB jobs use baremetal-full-deploy.yml playbook from extras
repository. Deprecate current ovb.yml playbook with message where
to make changes.

Change-Id: Ia8388b289a37c45b6c3d98bf27026599be16e9c7

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-16 23:18:35.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure the whole ResourceDefinition is validated

We used to validate intrinsic functions in the ResourceDefinition by just
passing it to function.validate(). That worked when it also acted as a
CloudFormation template snippet but, since that behaviour was removed by
2c6fc7bcd6b280a85488b0f32f8db7c7835f8b5c, that call now does nothing. This
replaces it with a validate() method on the ResourceDefinition itself.

This also improves path reporting for validation errors in deletion or
update policies.

Change-Id: I58c788002136ddf9bded309366e2072823b3ac77
Closes-Bug: #1732798'}]
commit_message:
Ensure the whole ResourceDefinition is validated

We used to validate intrinsic functions in the ResourceDefinition by just
passing it to function.validate(). That worked when it also acted as a
CloudFormation template snippet but, since that behaviour was removed by
2c6fc7bcd6b280a85488b0f32f8db7c7835f8b5c, that call now does nothing. This
replaces it with a validate() method on the ResourceDefinition itself.

This also improves path reporting for validation errors in deletion or
update policies.

Change-Id: I58c788002136ddf9bded309366e2072823b3ac77
Closes-Bug: #1732798

commit_message:
Add uWSGI support

This patch implements uWSGI support for ironic API service.
ironic/api/app.wsgi is deprecated in favor of pbr generated
ironic-api-wsgi

Co-Authored-By: anascko <ovoshchana@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ieb68c1042e31b77f9a549fd90afe31a65008deca
Closes-Bug: #1719260
Closes-Bug: #1668966

commit_message:
Define GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT before use

GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT was defined in scripts library and used in
gate-check-commit. When script library is loaded before using in
gate-check-commit, everything is fine. But when gate-check-commit
is doing upgrades, the checkout of previous branch happens before
the loading of the script library, which therefore loads previous
version of the script library which doesn't contain the
GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT environment variable, and therefore the usage
of this variable fails.

Change-Id: Ica58331d8c63d354561aebefd1b1e26dc2b37ffb
